Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, probably an ovoid neck-amphora, with handle root on right; exterior: from top, added red and black tongues with dilute brown lines in between; black-figure decoration consisting of judgment of Paris: at right of panel, Paris (head, neck, and shoulders remaining) probably moving to right and looking back; bearded, wearing red fillet, long faded added white chiton and red mantle over both shoulders; beside his beard on left, part of a fist holding a possible wreath; inscription on exterior.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Naukratis ("Picked up by Mr. Chester in the soil of Tel el Nebireh, the site of Naukratis" (British Museum register).)
Curator's comments: For the subject, see Louvre CA 616, a tripod kothon by the C Painter (ABV, 58, no. 122; Boardman, J., Athenian Black Figure Vases. London, 1974, fig. 38; LIMC VII, sv Paridis iudicium, no. 6, dated 570-560 BC; between Hermes and Paris there is a fourth woman holding a wreath.) The fist holding the wreath could be Hera’s (Beazley and Payne 1929, 261). Marked on reverse with black ink: "Tel el Nabeireh Jan: 17.1885 G.J.C". This refers to the Reverend Greville John Chester who, according to Petrie's personal diaries, visited Petrie at Naukratis in January 1885. Chester collected the sherd and then presented it to the British Museum upon his return to London.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B599.1)

Acquisition name: Donated by: Rev Greville John Chester
